display_asset.caption: A man in a sequoia tree in downtown Seattle on Tuesday. He has rebuffed the authorities’ attempts to negotiate.

summaries.body: An agitated man who climbed an 80-foot sequoia tree in Seattle has refused to come down for more than 20 hours, creating a national spectacle.

display_asset.caption: The mountain lion known as P-22 who lives in Griffith Park in Los Angeles.

summaries.body: The prime suspect in a koala's death at Los Angeles Zoo is a mountain lion named P-22. It appears to have motive, opportunity and the means to climb a nine-foot fence.

display_asset.caption: Jackson Hole, a community in Hebei Province, on the outskirts of Beijing, mimics the aesthetics of Jackson Hole valley in Wyoming.
display_asset.credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times

summaries.body: There is a Vancouver Forest in Beijing and a Thames Town in Shanghai. But China is now calling for an end to “foreign” and “bizarre” names for housing developments.

display_asset.caption: Riders in Los Angeles board a Megabus for San Francisco. The company’s terms and conditions limit its liability for baggage to $250.
display_asset.credit: Richard Hartog/Los Angeles Times, via Getty Images

summaries.body: A few weeks after a Megabus caught fire, many of the passengers have encountered a lack of recourse to collect compensation on thousands of dollars in lost property.

display_asset.caption: Billy Joel, performing at Madison Square Garden in December 2014.

summaries.body: Billy Joel’s “Piano Man” and John Coltrane’s “A Love Supreme” are part of a diverse crop of new inductees to the Library of Congress’ National Recording Registry.
The colors of Belgium’s black, yellow and red flag were reflected on famous landmarks, including the Eiffel Tower, around the world on Tuesday in a show of solidarity.
In Fresno, Calif., a mirrored headboard caught the sun in just the right way (or perhaps just the wrong way), and burned a family’s carport to a crisp.

display_asset.caption: Kevin Hart at the Academy Awards.

summaries.body: The comedian Kevin Hart will publish a memoir that explores his early troubles. “My kids know I’m a big deal," he said, adding, “Now I’ll have a book out to prove it.”

posts.footer: — Nick Denton, the founder of Gawker. The online news organization has been ordered to pay more than $140 million in damages for invading the privacy of the wrestler Hulk Hogan. Gawker

display_asset.credit: Eve Edelheit/Tampa Bay Times, via AP

summaries.body: We now know that the trial was a sham from the start.

display_asset.caption: Mark Davis, the Raiders’ owner, in 2014. “There’s nothing we can do,” Davis said Tuesday of talks with the city of Oakland about a new stadium. “We are in a holding pattern.”

summaries.body: Despite the criticism the N.F.L. has received over gambling and daily fantasy sports, the Oakland Raiders' owner says he is still looking for ways to move the team to Las Vegas.

display_asset.caption: David Chang’s next place will deliver food in the style of his Momofuku restaurants.

summaries.body: The next restaurant by David Chang, the chef behind Momofuku, will be delivery only. “It’s sort of my dream restaurant,” he said of a space that diners can't complain about.

display_asset.caption: Lauren Bacall in “To Have and Have Not.” A class-action complaint is seeking to prevent films with tobacco imagery from receiving G, PG or PG-13 ratings.

summaries.body: A class-action complaint seeking to prevent films with tobacco imagery from receiving anything but R ratings was assigned to a federal judge on Monday.

display_asset.caption: A group is led through an introductory course of meditation techniques at The Kitchen in Brooklyn.
display_asset.credit: Brian Harkin for The New York Times

summaries.body: Mind-based therapies may ease lower back pain with a combination of meditation, body awareness and yoga, a new study found.

display_asset.caption: The remains of the Doctors Without Borders hospital in Kunduz, Afghanistan, after it was hit by an American airstrike in October.

summaries.body: The new U.S. commander in Afghanistan apologized for the bombing of a Doctors Without Borders hospital in the northern city of Kunduz last October.

display_asset.caption: Gov. Nathan Deal, who has expressed doubts about proposals that might appear to tolerate discrimination, has until May 3 to reach a decision on what lawmakers named the Free Exercise Protection Act.

summaries.body: Companies and sports organizations could have an effect on the debate over a Georgia bill that would strengthen legal protections for opponents of same-sex marriage.

display_asset.caption: Taxis blocking a road in Jakarta, Indonesia, as public transportation drivers on Tuesday protested against ride-hailing apps.

summaries.body: The city center of Jakarta, Indonesia, was paralyzed Tuesday by a violent mass protest by taxi and other public transportation drivers against ride-hailing apps.

display_asset.caption: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, leader of the National League for Democracy party, at a session of Parliament in Myanmar last week. What her specific post in the new government will be may not be known for days.

summaries.body: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi will be a minister in Myanmar’s new government, according to a list of nominees for cabinet positions released on Tuesday.
Americans are more obese than ever, despite the fact that the percentage of those who exercise has steadily increased.

display_asset.caption: A room at Pod 39 in New York. Large chains are now planning microhotel projects.
display_asset.credit: Pablo Enriquez for The New York Times

summaries.body: To fight competition from Airbnb and appeal to younger travelers (and light packers, apparently), large hotel chains are offering rooms as small as 65 square feet.
Taxes on the sale of recreational marijuana in January netted Oregon $3.48 million, surpassing projections of $2 million to $3 million for the entire year.

display_asset.caption: Darius McCollum, who has Asperger’s syndrome, is currently in jail at Rikers Island on charges that he stole a Greyhound bus.

summaries.body: The story of New York's best-known train and bus thief will become a movie, but the M.T.A. says it will seek his royalties. “They will take it over my dead body,” his lawyer said.

display_asset.caption: A bald eagle at “Raptor Alley” near the refuge.
display_asset.credit: Dave Seminara for The New York Times

summaries.body: An Oregon wildlife refuge that was the site of a 41-day occupation has reopened, just in time for a bird festival. “The publicity has been huge for us,” a local official said.

display_asset.caption: A dickey sold at Tip Top.
display_asset.credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times

summaries.body: In Borough Park, one of the most heavily Hasidic areas of Brooklyn, new stores are helping Jews adhere to the rules of modesty without forfeiting sartorial flair.
Days after Val-Jean McDonald's open-coffin funeral in December, a Bronx funeral home called her family to tell them the body in it had not been hers.

display_asset.caption: A computer image of the research vessel, which is still being designed and is scheduled to set sail in 2019.

summaries.body: R.R.S. Boaty McBoatface is the front-runner in a British agency's proposal to let the Internet name a research ship. It is the latest case of web users having fun with public polls.

display_asset.caption: A polio vaccine was tested at a government lab in Kunming, China, last year. Over a dozen suspect products have been identified, including vaccines for rabies, polio, meningitis, hepatitis B and mumps, officials in the Chinese province of Shandong said.

summaries.body: The police in China said they had uncovered a criminal ring suspected of selling improperly stored vaccines in dozens of provinces.
North Korea launched several short-range projectiles off its east coast, the South Korean military said. The projectiles flew about 125 miles before landing in the sea.

display_asset.credit: Nancy Borowick for The New York Times

summaries.body: As New York City sets new recycling goals, it is cracking down on scavengers who pick metals, cardboard and plastic from the trash for money.
"Work." "Sorry." "Hello." A researcher has a few theories about why a growing number of hit songs have one-word titles.

display_asset.caption: The Shukhov Tower.

summaries.body: The Shukhov Tower in Moscow, a landmark from the '20s, has been put on a list of endangered global cultural heritage sites.
